item.title: Detroit's Bumpy Road
item.description: Continuing their somnambulistic ways, the Pistons dropped their conference-final opener to Miami. Plus: Offensive visionaries meet out West; Oilers on fire; Philly's cash hoard; Bonds show closes; Seahawks versus ref; and Watford's magical moment.

item.title: Immigration Costs Move to Fore
item.description: What would it cost U.S. taxpayers to put millions of illegal immigrants on the path to citizenship? Two widely differing estimates are drawing attention to the costs of federal benefits that low-skilled immigrant workers could be entitled to.

item.title: Should the Net Be Neutral?
item.description: The "net neutrality" debate has reached a fever pitch as Congress mulls legislation that would allow phone companies to charge Web sites for preferred delivery of digital content. Craigslist founder Craig Newmark and Mike McCurry, head of a phone industry group, debate the issue.

item.title: Apple's Rivals Need Design Mojo
item.description: The differences between Microsoft, Intel and Apple's approaches have more to do with aesthetics than manufacturing, Lee Gomes says.

item.title: Mavs' Classic Victory
item.description: In a series for the ages, the Dallas Mavericks advanced to the NBA finals by beating the defending-champion San Antonio Spurs. Up next for the Mavs: The Phoenix Suns and their potent, Steve Nash-led offense.

item.title: Backing Away From Bush
item.description: With Bush's job-approval ratings skidding as low as 30% in national polls, there are more places where a presidential appearance could hurt Republican candidates.

item.title: Web Advertisers Find Offline Ads Can Pay
item.description: Internet companies are starting to move beyond banners and pricy paid search ads back to more traditional channels like television, radio and print.

item.title: Domain Name Could Spur Wireless Web
item.description: A new company aims to make it easier to browse the Internet on mobile devices, such as cellphones and BlackBerries, by setting up a new domain name specifically for wireless Web sites called dot-mobi.

item.title: Interleague Animosity
item.description: In Chicago, New York and two California cities, baseball rivals crossed league boundaries to deliver a brawl, several thrillers and No. 714. Plus: So long, LeBron; and could Barbaro's cruel fate have been averted?

item.title: Finding the Gaps in Tighter Borders
item.description: Better security on the Mexican border may do little to reduce illegal immigration. Similar strategies have been tried in the past and failed, and since then smugglers have gotten smarter.

item.title: Student TV Appears on the Web
item.description: Open Student TV Network is part of a burst of TV channels targeting college students, mostly over the Internet. The network also provides a distribution system for shows produced by students.

item.title: All Hail the Middleman
item.description: Disintermediation? Not in this columnist's digital life: There are middlemen everywhere, and thank goodness.

item.title: Broadcasters Fight FCC Fines
item.description: The FCC's effort to get tough on indecency may be backfiring as broadcasters get more brazen in their efforts to fight back.

item.title: Anti-Union Organization Broadens Message
item.description: An advocacy group with an unusually broad antiunion message is now bringing its marketing campaign to TV. The spot is aimed at raising awareness about what the group sees as the corrupt practices of organized labor.

item.title: Lobbying Case to Get Jury Test
item.description: The Justice Department is about to find out whether its investigation of the Abramoff lobbying scandal can pass muster with a jury. David Safavian, a former White House official, is set to go on trial.

item.title: Cavs Push Pistons to the Brink
item.description: The Cavaliers pulled off a stunner on the road, taking a 3-2 lead in their playoff series against the Pistons. Can Detroit return to form before it's too late? Plus: Duncan's Laettner-esque night; the NHL's surprise Final Four; Barcelona's triumph; and more.

item.title: Flak Over 'Fast Food Nation'
item.description: As the movie "Fast Food Nation" prepares to have its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, U.S. food companies are rallying to rebut allegations in the film and a new book that fast-food chains contribute to obesity and other problems.

item.title: Servicing Computer Networks From Afar
item.description: The latest wrinkle for outsourcing companies in India is long-distance monitoring of corporate computer networks in U.S. and Europe -- services that could be worth tens of billions of dollars.

item.title: Vonage Faces User Complaints
item.description: Internet phone-service provider Vonage is confronting complaints of poor sound quality, dropped calls and other glitches as it plans to move forward with its initial public offering.

item.title: Stolen Season
item.description: Dwyane Wade's steal ended the New Jersey Nets' season and brought the Miami Heat closer to an NBA crown. Plus: The Clippers lose a heartbreaker in Phoenix; a wild night in the Bronx; and advice for the Sharks. And get the latest from the Fix's seasonlong baseball contest.

item.title: Green Politics Find Success at Local Level
item.description: Environmentalists are discovering that green politics, like other politics, is local. With little progress at the national level, green groups are joining with traditional adversaries on local issues and making some inroads.

item.title: Churches Embrace the Web
item.description: In a bid to attract new members and shed their persistently Luddite image, churches are embracing technology and Web sites like MySpace.

item.title: How Apple's Store Strategy Beat the Odds
item.description: As Apple prepares to take the wraps off its most ambitious store yet -- on New York's Fifth Avenue -- there are few left who doubt Jobs's retail strategy. The stores have been an unlikely success story in an area littered with failures.

item.title: Questions for … Richard Edelman
item.description: Public-relations executive Richard Edelman talks about the need for transparency in PR and the rising use of the Web.

item.title: Too Cavalier
item.description: The Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Detroit Pistons, making Rasheed Wallace regret his boast that their series would be over by Wednesday. Plus: The Mavericks outlast the Spurs; life without the Lakers; and farewell to Flutie.

item.title: Balancing Privacy and Security
item.description: Can both national security and privacy rights be protected in the digital age? Privacy advocate Marc Rotenberg and security consultant Kim Taipale discuss.

item.title: Rove's Camp Takes Center of Web Storm
item.description: An Internet posting set off a media frenzy by saying Rove had been indicted, and bloggers have changed reporting dynamics as more people turn to the Web for news.

item.title: Anonymous Earmarks Continue
item.description: The House continues to draft spending bills, despite probes, that set aside billions for home-state projects without disclosing sponsors.

item.title: Many Say U.S. Isn't Equipped for Disasters
item.description: Many Americans express concerns about the federal government's ability to handle another hurricane disaster, a new Harris poll shows.

item.title: Remembering Patterson
item.description: Floyd Patterson, who became the youngest heavyweight champion 50 years ago before succumbing to Sonny Liston's fury, died last week at age 71. Plus: NBA > NCAA; Brown run out of town?; Alou and Baker stay put; how to say sorry; a memorable NHL prank; and more.

item.title: Republicans Seek to Revive Their Activists
item.description: Republicans plan to pursue a slew of judicial appointments in an effort to rally conservative voters discouraged by Bush's approval ratings.

item.title: Can 'Studio 60' Save NBC?
item.description: Hits are hard to predict in the TV business, but NBC thinks it has one in Aaron Sorkin's "Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip," a glitzy new drama about how hard it is to produce a hit in the TV business.

item.title: Me, Me, Me
item.description: The Web has made accessing far-flung news outlets, from tiny local papers to major foreign presses and every Web log and magazine in between, as simple as a couple of mouse clicks. But keeping that deluge of information organized hasn't been so easy for readers.

item.title: CIA Hearings May Bring Oversight Debate
item.description: Lawmakers plan to use the Hayden CIA confirmation hearings as a springboard for establishing increased monitoring of Defense Department operations put into place since 9/11.

item.title: Is the Phone Company Violating Your Privacy?
item.description: USA Today reported that three telecom firms -- AT&T, Verizon and BellSouth -- have been providing the National Security Agency with records of billions of domestic phone calls made by U.S. citizens. Here's a closer look.

item.title: Great Divide: CEO and Worker Pay
item.description: Failures in corporate governance play a big role in the widening gap between CEO and worker pay, economists say in the latest WSJ.com survey.

item.title: Yankees Must Regroup
item.description: The Yankees lost to the Red Sox Thursday, but must face a bigger loss: Left fielder Hideki Matsui broke his wrist and could miss the rest of the year. Plus: A great catch in Philadelphia; a brother's grief; the Clippers' biggest fan; and baseball players think pink.

item.title: Swamped Networks Are Surfing the Web
item.description: During this year's television "upfront," the TV schedule will play second fiddle to what networks are doing to help advertisers reach consumers in an age of digital video recorders and fast-growing Internet use.

item.title: Reversing Course on Electronic Voting
item.description: Some advocates of the Help America Vote Act, which mandated upgrades to voting machines, now worry that the overhaul is making things worse and have filed lawsuits to block several efforts to comply.

item.title: Scientists Explain Climate-Change Data
item.description: For laypeople, one of the toughest things about science isn't understanding what science knows, but grasping how it knows what it knows. Case in point: climate change.

item.title: Bush's Ratings Hit a New Low
item.description: Bush's job-approval rating has fallen to its lowest mark of his presidency, according to a new Harris Interactive poll.

item.title: The NBA's Playoff Paradox
item.description: The second round of the NBA playoffs have seen something strange: close series featuring blowout games. Plus: Coaches' tales; the Oilers rebound; A-Rod's revenge; and more.

item.title: Putting a Price on Mom
item.description: What's the dollar value of work done by stay-at-home moms? One recent study suggests an annual salary of $134,121, but Carl Bialik says the calculation is rooted in murky math.

item.title: Auto Makers Wrap Themselves in U.S. Flag
item.description: As the American auto market grows more competitive, U.S. car makers are trying to regain their footing by appealing to patriotism. But a close look at one Japanese model shows that defining what is American isn't so easy these days.

item.title: Apple's Device Model Beats the PC Way
item.description: In early battles for dominance of the PC market, Microsoft's component-based platform crushed Apple's end-to-end model. But in today's post-PC era, where the focus is on music players, game consoles and cellphones, the end-to-end model is the early winner.

item.title: The Fastest Way to Get to the Airport
item.description: We sent five people to New York's JFK Airport using five different methods of transportation -- helicopter, car service, subway, bus and yellow cab -- to see who would get there first.

item.title: Most Americans Try to Guard Personal Data
item.description: Few Americans say they have been victims of identity fraud, according to a new WSJ.com/Harris personal-finance poll. But a strong majority are still taking steps to prevent the theft of personal and financial information that can lead to fraud.

item.title: Pierre Leaves Bonds Unlucky
item.description: A leaping catch by the Cubs' Juan Pierre kept Barry Bonds behind Babe Ruth in the home-run record books. Plus: Bosox pound Yanks; a change for the Kings; resisting a hockey cliché; and how to shoot free throws.

item.title: Katherine Harris Battles Old Friends
item.description: Instead of gratefully supporting U.S. Senate candidacy of Katherine Harris, who as Florida secretary of state oversaw the 2000 presidential recount, the Republican establishment just wishes she'd go away.

item.title: Americans Are Scarce in Top Tech Contest
item.description: Only four of the 48 best computer programmers in the world are Americans. Is this more evidence of a sad decline in American education and competitiveness?

item.title: Gore-Led Group to Focus on Global Warming
item.description: A Gore-backed group intends to spend millions of dollars in an effort to convince Americans global warming is an urgent problem.

item.title: Barbaro Fever
item.description: Barbaro ran off with the Kentucky Derby, sparking all manner of Triple Crown talk and even invocations of the great Secretariat. Plus: Bonds faces down the crowd in Philly.

item.title: Al Gore Might Yet Join 2008 Contenders
item.description: Favorable publicity surrounding Al Gore's movie "An Inconvenient Truth" is stoking serious speculation about a political comeback for the former vice president.

item.title: Comedy Central Corners the Laughs Business
item.description: Comedy Central is using its strength in television to diversify into other parts of the laughs business. In the past four years the channel has built a record label and has become a major player in the comedy-tour business.

item.title: Where Are They Now: George Gilder
item.description: The 2001 stock-market bust wiped out most of George Gilder's fan base and fortune, but the conservative pundit hasn't lost faith in tech stocks.

item.title: Box-Office Challenge
item.description: Stat Snapshot: Marketing "United 93" was never going to be easy, but Universal's strategy for stirring up buzz couldn't provide a box-office boost.

item.title: Music's Merger Mania
item.description: Taking a page from the corporate world, many arts groups are tying the knot. But the result is often imperfect harmony. The upswing in these deals reflects an arts world coming to terms with an extended slump: Having tried everything from laser-light shows to performances of movie soundtracks to attract new audiences, some are now giving up their independence to survive.

item.title: Gaming Industry's Hopes Hang on New Boxes
item.description: Sony and Nintendo will show functioning versions of their new consoles for the first time at the annual Electronic Entertainment Expo next week.

item.title: A Hard-to-Predict Run for the Roses
item.description: Brother Derek leads the list of Derby favorites, but handicappers say the field is deep. Plus: The media flocks to the story of Brother Derek's trainer; Kobe falls short; a Shaq attack; high rollers; and a former Wolfpack's homecoming.

item.title: Females Don't Always Go for Hottest Mate
item.description: Just as Darwin's theory of natural selection is under attack by America's religious right, his less-known theory of sexual selection is catching flak from some biologists.

item.title: Cheney Turns Up Rhetorical Heat on Putin
item.description: Cheney criticized Putin for political repression and use of oil and gas as "tools of intimidation or blackmail."

item.title: Two Visions of the Internet's Future
item.description: What will the Internet look like 10 years from now? Vint Cerf, one of the Web's pioneers, and tech pundit Esther Dyson share their thoughts on what's in store for the next decade.

item.title: Earl Woods, 1932-2006
item.description: Earl Woods died at age 74. The ex-Green Beret and groundbreaking college-baseball star lived to see most of his outlandish predictions about his son Tiger borne out. Plus: LeBron v. Gilbert; Nats' new patron; Bonds's curse; and the rules of boobirds.

item.title: Microsoft Bids for Web-Search Ads
item.description: Microsoft revealed adCenter, an auction system it hopes to use to tap into online advertising dollars and compete with Google.

item.title: Tech Firms Check Earlier for Flaws
item.description: In the past, software engineers were often under pressure to work as fast as they could, but now many companies are teaching programmers to write safer code and test their security as they are built.

item.title: Support for Roe v. Wade Declines
item.description: U.S. support for Roe v. Wade is at its lowest level in decades, according to a new Harris poll, with a slim 49% to 47% plurality of U.S. adults now favoring the 1973 Supreme Court decision on abortion.

item.title: Lakers-Suns Spells Trouble
item.description: The Lakers are in trouble after an ugly loss to the Suns, with Kwame Brown and Raja Bell facing troubles of their own. Plus: Meet the (nice) Nets; Flyers check out; paging Al Bundy to Wrigley, stat; L'Affaire Foley; and N.C. State can't find a coach.

item.title: Movie Studios See Rise in Piracy Estimates
item.description: U.S. movie studios are losing about $6.1 billion in revenue a year to global piracy, about 75% more than thought. The surprising results to the industry study have left studios debating how to release the information.

item.title: Sudan Divestment Push Stirs Ire
item.description: A campaign to persuade universities and public pension funds to shed investments in companies doing business in Sudan is generating a backlash from fund managers and business groups.

item.title: The Best of the Worst
item.description: The Internet gave rise to countless dot-com duds, but some ideas still stand out for pure silliness. Even years later, these business ventures leave people scratching their heads. Take a look back at CueCat, Flooz, the iLoo and more. (Plus, join a discussion.)

item.title: Boston Draws First Blood
item.description: The Red Sox won a thriller over the Yankees in a game that boasted intriguing subplots, too. Plus: The Clippers move on; shock in Edmonton; two baseball surprises; and Churchill Downs intrigue.

item.title: Federal Agencies May Fill the Freedom Tower
item.description: The Freedom Tower is likely to be a government citadel housing federal law-enforcement groups -- possibly enhancing its profile as a terrorist target. If more federal or state tenants don't sign on, the development deal could unravel.

item.title: Different Paths to Same Goal
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of immigrants snarled the streets of Los Angeles in dueling demonstrations in support of a common goal, but separated by diametrically opposed tactics.

item.title: Law-Firm Life Doesn't Suit Some Associates
item.description: More associates at law firms across the U.S. are second guessing whether they want to sign over their lives to their jobs.

item.title: E-Commerce Laggards
item.description: A decade after the birth of e-commerce, some retailers are still struggling to get their online acts together. Some companies frustrate shoppers with clunky checkouts and limited selections, while others still don't sell anything online.

item.title: Kobe's MJ Act
item.description: Kobe Bryant's two buzzer-beaters led the Lakers to a 3-1 series lead over the Phoenix Suns. Besides Phoenix, three other favorites are struggling to advance to the second round. Plus: Red Wings' Revelation Day; and draft winners and losers.

item.title: Democrats Put Minimum Wage on the Ballot
item.description: Democrats expect state ballot initiatives to raise minimum wages will boost party turnout and improve the party's odds in November.

item.title: Newly Rich Play Financier in Silicon Valley
item.description: New wealth from stock options and an improving tech economy is nurturing a fresh crop of Silicon Valley investors and spurring a revival in so-called angel investing.

item.title: The Internet on the Big Screen
item.description: Filmmakers love high-tech plotlines, but a look at movies from the past decade shows that Hollywood has a spotty track record when it comes to accurate big-screen portrayals of the Internet.

item.title: Studio Woos Women Turned Off by Cruise
item.description: Paramount is working hard to market the new "Mission: Impossible" sequel to women, as audience research indicates Tom Cruise's off-screen conduct may have rattled his female fan base.

item.title: Bloggers Debate Galbraith's Legacy
item.description: Online pundits weighed in on the life and legacy of John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard professor, liberal economist and backstage politician.

item.title: The Pros, Cons of Immigration Boycotts
item.description: Hispanic-Americans confront a dilemma on the eve of the Great American Boycott. Disrupting commerce and education could backfire in the near term by making it more difficult for lawmakers to support a guest-worker program now.

item.title: Power Play: Hockey Tries to Woo Celebs
item.description: As the race for the Stanley Cup heats up, the NHL is trying to raise its profile by getting celebrities in the stands where they can see and be seen.

item.title: Rumors of Critic's Demise
item.description: The Web, television and stupendous marketing budgets have radically transformed the dynamics of movie marketing. So how does this new model affect the role of the film reviewer?

item.title: Bush Backs Raising Fuel Standards
item.description: Bush and Senate Republican leaders backed new measures to shift the burden of gasoline prices to car makers and oil companies in response to growing public anger.

item.title: Red Sox Redux
item.description: Bill Buckner's through-the-legs mishap at first base in the 1986 World Series remains the ultimate error for legions of baseball fans. For one jobless 24-year-old, the gaffe -- and an obsession with Nintendo -- provided a venue for online fame and an unlikely ticket out of unemployment.

item.title: Heat Get Scorched by Bulls
item.description: The Bulls made the Heat look old in their playoff matchup, but veteran Alonzo Mourning may provide a boost to Miami. Plus: NHL players' athletic supporters; Delmon's rage; the Curse of Barry; the draft's only relevant player; and club and country in soccer.

item.title: Film Critics on 'United 93'
item.description: A roundup of film critics' reviews of "United 93."

item.title: Congressional-Bribe Case May Widen
item.description: Prosecutors are investigating whether two contractors supplied former Rep. Randall Cunningham with prostitutes and free use of a limousine and hotel suites, pursuing evidence that could broaden their long-running inquiry.

item.title: Flyers Dull Sabres
item.description: The Philadelphia Flyers rebounded from a horrifying loss to defeat the Buffalo Sabres in a tough, physical third game of their playoff series. Plus: More from the NHL; Bonds isn't quite through yet; two NBA tales; and another go-round for Favre.

item.title: Republicans Sag in New Poll
item.description: Spiking gas prices have intensified discontent with Washington. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found 77% of Americans uneasy about the economy. Bush's approval rating fell to 36%, with Congressional approval at 22%.

item.title: Measuring Chernobyl's Fallout
item.description: How many people died because of the Chernobyl nuclear-reactor explosion? Twenty years after the disaster, the death toll remains in dispute. Plus, two recent studies reach different conclusions on the high-school dropout rate, and more.

item.title: New Sun CEO Is Unconventional
item.description: Sun promoted a brainy insider who promises to stay the computer maker's maverick course, prompting the question: Does Jonathan Schwartz have the management chops to revive a Silicon Valley giant?

item.title: Stations Still Allow Packaged 'News'
item.description: Local television stations are again under fire for using pre-packaged video news releases without disclosing their origin. Joe Flint says increasing cost pressures are driving stations to soften ethical standards.

item.title: Bonds in Twilight
item.description: Barry Bonds hit his 710th home run, but watching him on the bases and in the field has become the stuff of pity. Sort of. Plus: Heartbreak for the Kings; the Wizards get tough; quick hits from the NHL playoffs; and another vacation for Rickey.

item.title: What Will It Take to Be the Next No. 1?
item.description: Dozens of start-ups are trying to do to MySpace what MySpace did to the first big social-networking site, Friendster. Lee Gomes asks four about their strategy.

item.title: Immigration Policy and Nationality
item.description: A strong majority of Americans say nationality shouldn't be a factor in U.S. immigration policy, according to a new Harris poll. But many support favorable treatment of immigrants under certain conditions.

item.title: Fox News Seeks $1 a Subscriber
item.description: Fox News Channel is seeking to increase the distribution fees paid by cable and satellite operators to $1 dollar per month per subscriber, up from the 25 cent to 35 cent subscriber fee the network currently earns.

item.title: Does the Pope Wear Prada?
item.description: Pope Benedict XVI is appealing to a new group of admirers: marketers seeking not blessings but pontifical product placements.

item.title: Ruff Treatment for Flyers
item.description: The Philadelphia Flyers were humiliated by the Buffalo Sabres, leading to a war of words between the teams' coaches. Plus: Stars, Rangers face 0-2 holes; the Heat hold off the Bulls; and the Clippers are halfway home.

item.title: Republicans Take Aim at Oil
item.description: Republican anxiety at rising gas prices led Frist and Hastert to urge a gouging probe, and Bush to comply.

item.title: Supermarkets Ranked Highest for Service
item.description: Americans rank supermarkets highest among various industries at serving customers, a recent Harris poll shows.

item.title: Bargains From Bordeaux? Believe It.
item.description: You can find quite a few inexpensive 2003 Bordeaux wines pretty much everywhere. How are they? To put it simply: even more delightful than we expected.
